awd_titl_txt: Maurice Auslander Distinguished Lectures and International Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2018 Maurice Auslander International Conference will be held at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute, Quissett Campus in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, USA on April 25-31, 2018. Conferences are also planned for the last week of April in 2019 and 2020. These meetings will be a center of activity for the representation theory of finite dimensional algebras. Each conference will be a combination workshop/conference/student presentation event and will serve three principal objectives: (a) to improve understanding of basic background knowledge in the field of representations of finite dimensional algebras and related topics, (b) to keep participants up to date on the newest developments in the field and (c) to give early-career, US-based researchers an opportunity to showcase their results to an international audience.
 
The conferences will bring together researchers working in representation theory and related areas of combinatorics, invariant theory, commutative algebra, homological algebra, and mathematical physics. Each day of the conference will start with an expository lecture by a prominent international expert. This will be followed by one or two presentations by students. The rest of the lectures will be traditional conference talks. The last day of the conference will be devoted to mathematical physics and its relation to representation theory. The conference website is http://www.northeastern.edu/martsinkovsky/p/MADL/MADL.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Auslander Conference used to be held every year in April or May in Woods Hole. However, due to the pandemic, there was some delay and change in dates. These events sponsored by the National Science Foundation were held at  the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Quissett Campus, on April 25-30, 2018, April 24-29, 2019 and October 26-30, 2022.
 
The Maurice Auslander International Conference is an international meeting centered around a branch of Algebra called Representation Theory. With continued funding from the National Science Foundation, in 2018, 2019 and 2022 this event was very successful. The goal of the conference is to invite prominent mathematicians from around the world to share their knowledge, ideas and methods, especially with the many beginning researcher, mostly from the USA, who come to learn and to announce their results. Each year about half of the participants are students or postdocs and about one third of the lectures are by these young people. Each day the conference starts with an invited Expository Lecture by an established expert. These are intended to be colloquium style lectures. For example, in 2018, Amihay Hanany from Imperial College, London, gave an Expository Lecture about supersymmetric gauge theory and representation theory. In 2019, Alastair King from University of Bath, UK, gave an Expository Lecture about stability conditions and cluster theory. In 2022, Ralph Kaufmann from Perdue University, gave an Expository Lecture on Feynman Categories.
 
While the main topic of the conference is Representation Theory, the lectures show a strong relationship between Representation Theory and other fields of study such as Mathematical Physics as mentioned above, Algebraic Combinatorics and applications such as Topological Data Analysis. For example, in 2018, Mboyo Esole and Rak-Kyeong Seong gave talks about Representation Theory and String Theory. Emily Gunawan, Peter Jorgensen and Ralf Schiffler in 2019 and Karin Baur in 2018 gave talks about the algebra of Friezes which has recently become a hot topic in Algebraic Combinatorics and its relation to Cluster Theory. In 2022, we had two talks related to Topological Data Analysis by Thomas Brustle and Eric Hanson.
 
Proceedings of the 2018 Auslander Conference, including some major contributions such as expanded notes from the Distinguished Lectures of Amnon Neeman on Triangulated Categories and Ralph Kaufmann's treatis on Feynman Categories have been published in 2021 in one volume of Contemporary Mathematics entitled ?Representations of Algebras, Geometry and Physics.?
The Auslander Conference has become a successful major international event thanks largely to the continued support of the National Science Foundation. Participants can expect both workshop style Expository Lectures and research talks at a high level. All talks are plenary and enjoy a full audience of international experts, giving an opportunity for students to talk about their research and the results of their PhD theses and get valuable feedback from a team of experts. Students and postdoc also have an opportunity to make contacts and begin collaborations as they present their work to the larger mathematical research community.
